alert.note: Alert for King (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 8:19AM PST until March 02 at 12:55AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Tolt River Above Carnation affecting King County. Snoqualmie River Near Snoqualmie Falls affecting King County. Snoqualmie River Near Carnation affecting King County. .A strong storm is coming in to western Washington with multiple factors that will produce high runoff and flooding. Heavy, prolonged rainfall will be coupled with some snow snow melt in low to mid elevations of the mountains from rising snow levels and strong warm and moist winds. This will drive some rivers above minor to major flooding. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON TO EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Snoqualmie River Near Snoqualmie Falls. * WHEN...From this afternoon to early Wednesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 41000.0 cfs, the Snoqualmie River will cause major flooding from the town of Snoqualmie downstream through Fall City...inundating most of the farm land in the flood plain...some residential areas...and many roads. Flood waters will be deep and swift in some areas. Flooding will occur all along the river including headwaters...tributaries...and other streams within and near the Snoqualmie River Basin. This river level on the Snoqualmie corresponds roughly to a phase 4 flood in the King County flood system. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:30 AM PST Monday the flow was 6270.0 cfs. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon to a crest of 43250 cfs late this evening. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon. - Flood flow is 20000.0 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 43200.0 cfs on 11/20/1962. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this afternoon at 415 PM PST.
